title: 30's metal type
content:
This is a bit from a Soviet propaganda publication from the 30's. Any ideas?   
   
-j ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20110812193247im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/19372.gif)
author: tuca

comments.content:
Helvetica it can't be, wasn't it designed in the '50s?   
   
I can't think of an exact match, but I'd suggest you to   
take a look at [Grotesque MT](http://web.archive.org/web/20110812193247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/grotesque-mt/grotesque-mt/testdrive.html?s=STATE%20PUBLISHING&p=48) and [Bureau Grotesque 51](http://web.archive.org/web/20110812193247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/bureau-grotesque/bureaugrotesque-fiveone/testdrive.html?s=STATE%20PUBLISHING&p=48),   
(for some digital alternatives).

Helvetica in the 30s?   
   
And the 'R' and 'C' don't look Helvetica to me...

and the letter "S" has a specific form, doesn't it?   
   
Stalin Sans Pic?

Hmmm... [not exactly](http://web.archive.org/web/20110812193247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/helvetica/helvetica/testdrive.html?s=PUBLISHING%20SOCIALIST%20ARTICLE&p=24). It's one of the grotesques that   
preceded it and on which Helvetica is inspired. It's not   
Akzidenz-Grotesk for sure.

_\> Helvetica it can't be, wasn't it designed in the '50s?_   
_\> Helvetica in the 30s?_   
   
I hear ya I hear ya get off my back! ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20110812193247im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)
